Well you wouldn't be here, I mean at all. Which I'd have to say would be an upside.
What good did you think could possibly come from writing her that letter?
What harm could come from it? Pause as they eye each other up.
So that's it? You came all the way from England to give me a lecture, I'm impressed. Or did you just happen to be in town?
No, I came because I couldn't let my grandmother come on her own.
Claire's here? Why?
I think even you might be able to work that one out.
Oh my God, she's come to find her Alfonso, that's awesome, I want to meet her.  32.
I want to play for Manchester United but I'm shit at football.
You honestly don't think she'd want to meet me?
I honestly think she has no interest in meeting a woman who can Manage to jam "oh my God" and "awesome" into the same sentence.
Did you ask her?
It just wouldn't occur to her.
Where are you staying?
(laughs) D'you really think I'm that stupid?
I haven't decided yet. A beat. Charlie gets up from the table.
Why did you come here tonight?

I was just curious to see what kind of imbecile would think writing that letter was such a great idea. I should've known it'd be an American. Good night. He strides out of the restaurant. Sophia is appalled at h rudeness and is stuck to her chair for a moment. She looks across the room at Victor serving The Secretari their entrees. They applaud his efforts. He's beaming. Sophia thinks for a beat. Then grabs her coat and leaves.  33.

Sophia emerges from the restaurant and looks around to se which way Charlie has gone. She spots him and starts to follow him at a discreet distance. Claire Smith - room 32.

Sophia walks down the hallway to room 32. She's nervous a she takes a deep breath and knocks on the door. She adjus her hair and straightens her dress. The door opens. And h face drops as she is confronted by Charlie.
(whispers) What the bloody hell are you doing here? He moves out pulling the door semi-closed behind him.
I think maybe even you can work that one out.
I told you she doesn't want to meet you.
You told me it wouldn't occur to her to want to meet me. A voice comes from inside the room.  34.

(shouts) My name is Sophia. I wrote the letter.
Well for goodness sake come in. Charlie looks daggers at her then reluctantly opens the d

Sophia walks into the room and there she is, CLAIRE SMITH regal beauty at the age of seventy two. She gets up and f fleeting moment, bathed in a Veronese backlight, she almo looks like the fifteen year old who sent that letter all those years ago. They take each other’s hand and don’t let go. They take a long look at each other - so many questions on either sid
You look like I thought you'd look.
Since you wrote to a fifteen-year- old I'll take that as a compliment. Sophia smiles. Claire smiles. Charlie isn't smiling.
How did you find us?
Charlie found me, actually. Claire turns to Charlie who shrugs as if to say "surprise
He told me you were here and said you might like to meet me.
How uncharacteristically thoughtful of you dear. Slight pause. He looks at Sophia who smiles innocently.  35.
Well, in the circumstances, it seemed a little churlish not to meet the person responsible for this voyage of lunacy.
Charlie doesn’t approve. Which makes it all the more fun. Would you like some tea? Oh no, of course, you’re American. We'll order coffee. Charlie? He obediently goes to the phone.
They all sit having coffee while Claire talks.
I waited for a reply to that letter for two years. Once I even plucked up the courage to run away and find him. But it only lasted as far as Waterloo Station, I’m afraid.
So why is it you never mentioned him to me till last week then?

It was such a long time ago, dear. And I met your grandfather and over the years I did my best to forget that summer in Tuscany and the bronzed Adonis of a boy who kissed me for the first time. He was the first person to ever tell me I was beautiful. And boy did it sound more romantic in Italian.
I'll bet.
“Clara, siete cosi bella.”
But you and Gramps were happy enough, weren’t you?  36.
That's exactly right - happy enough. We were a “good couple” with much to be grateful for. Except for you Charlie, you’ve been the bane of my existence. Sophia smiles, intrigued by these two.

Then when Jack died - there’s a lot of Jack in Charlie, funnily enough - I grieved profoundly for years. But as time went by his memory became a distant, warm glow, instead of a searing pain in my side. Then, unexpectedly, at odd hours of the day, in my dreams at night, I found myself thinking about Alfonso... which made it all the more extraordinary when, out of the blue, your letter arrived. I’m so grateful you wrote it. There were so many reasons not to.
I'll say.
So what happens now?
Well the thing is, I think we've found him.
Really? Where?
Just outside Verona. Quite close to where he used to live, actually.
No! That's incredible.
Charlie thinks it's a dreadful mistake.
It'll be fine, really it will. Sophia looks at her watch.
I’m so sorry. I have to go. I'm flying down to Palermo with my boyfriend for a few days before we go home. He’s found some kind of weird cheese down there.
(slightly disappointed) Of course you are. Thank you so much for the letter. 37. They hug. Sophia turns to Charlie who extends his hand stiffly.
It's been a pleasure.
I guess your idea of pleasure and mine are two very different things. For a moment he seems charmed by her directness and hones He smiles. Claire gives her a piece of paper.
My phone number back in London. Will you call me?
I will. I have to know how it ends.
Sophia and Victor are in the middle of packing Sophia's head is still in Claire's hotel room.
for Palermo. Victor is focused intently on packing, he's not really listening.
I so hope it works out for her...
Hmm.
I mean imagine if they found each other after fifty years...
That'd be something.  38.
Because I found a letter in a wall, it's crazy, it's like no story that's ever been told...
Right. Sophia pauses on this thought. Then the penny drops.
I have to write it.
You can start on the plane.
I have to stay. Victor's listening now.
Wait. What?
I have to know out how it ends.
What about Palermo? The cheese?
You don't need me for cheese. You can pick me up on your way back. I'll write. You taste. Win win. Sophia starts unpacking her suitcase. Victor stammers.
Can't we at least discuss this?
I started it. I have to finish it.
But? Who are these people? You're just gonna go off with them? They could be serial killers...

Killers who oh-so-cleverly planted a half century old love letter ina wall for me to find. How devious.  39. She smiles, keeps unpacking. Victor just stands there rac his brain for a reason she has to come with him.
But? Who's gonna take the pictures?
Sophia is walking through Claire's hotel on her cell phon

You can't actually think she'll find this guy? A hundred bucks says he's dead, married or gay.
But what if he's not? What if she does? What if that spark is still there after fifty years? He can't. He nods to himself. Takes a bite of an egg roll
Could be something there.
So I should write it?
You can write it. Doesn't mean I'll print it. Sophia smiles - good enough for her.
Sophia is standing at Claire's door. Charlie opens it.
Hi!
Oh God.  40.
Sophia, Claire and Charlie walk through the streets towar Juliet’s house. Charlie casts a disbelieving glance at So - What is she doing here?

Alfonso had such a way with plants. Working those fields was spiritual for him. He'd always talk about the land in Tuscany, the way it smelled, the moisture in the soil, perfect for the grapes he’d grow there one day. He used to say all he needed to be happy were days in those fields and nights with me. Sophia smiles at this.
When he was working I’d pray for the sun to come out because then he'd have to take off his shirt.
Nana!
He was so solid and brown. The sweat would glisten off his back like little jewels. The thought of it still sends shivers down my spine.
Alright, I think we get the picture.
What, you don't approve of your old Gran having carnal thoughts?
Oh for heaven's sake.
You're such a prude. And you're ageist.
I am not! I love old people.  4l.

Here we are. They walk into Juliet’s courtyard.
Gosh, I remember this so well. We were on our way home. I was so sad. Then I looked up at her an thought - she'd know what to do. I'll ask her.
Sorry it took her so long to get back to you. Claire smiles.
No matter. I'm here now. A familiar voice comes from behind them.
Is this her? Sophia turns and finds Bella holding a basket of the day' letters. Bella is looking at Claire.
Claire. This is Bella. She's one of The Secretaries.
Ah yes, another interfering busybody. Perfect. Neither Bella nor Claire pay him any mind. They smile.
It's such a pleasure to meet you.
And such an honor to meet you. Claire goes to shake her hand but Bella grabs her and hug her and kisses her on both cheeks.  42.
Claire is the guest of honor at the head of a table with Charlie, Sophia and the rest of The Secretaries. They're eating dinner. The Secretaries are all smiling at Claire.
Are you nervous?

A bit I suppose. What if I’ve turned him into something he isn’t? He’s always existed in my mind’s eye as a model of perfection. Like a ‘57 Bentley Continental. What if he’s actually a clapped out old Alfa Romeo with bundles of nose hair? What if he doesn’t remember me at all - if I was simply not to him what he was to me? Slight pause as they all think about this. Charlie wades
Right. Let’s go home then before it all ends in tears.
What is it with you? It's like you really don't want this to work out. Charlie is aghast at such a suggestion - a little too agh
I'm a realist not a fantasist, that's the point.
No it's not. The point is you're English.
No romance.
Lots of cynicism.
Cold as fish.
You don't have to be a cold fish to think the idea of true love lasting forever is ridiculous. (MORE)
CHARLIE (cont'd) Actually, come to that, the very idea of true love at all leaves one struggling.
Well in that case we take it all back. Everyone laughs except Charlie. Claire smiles softly at h
Charlie why don’t you get yourself out of the line of fire and settle the bill? He motions for the waiter to bring the bill. As soon as s sees this Angelina comes striding across the restaurant.
No charge.
I'm sorry we couldn't possibly...
I'm sorry, you can possibly. He looks at her - realizes this isn’t someone you mess wi
The Secretaries are walking with Claire, laughing and chatting. Charlie and Sophia follow at a short distance.
You know, I’m not the buttoned up, buttock clenching, killjoy you lot are trying to make me out to be.
Right. We made you argue that true love is ridiculous. Thanks for clearing that up.
It's just that I am genuinely worried for her.
She'll be fine.
Physically yes. But what if he breaks her heart? What if he laughs in her face? What if he doesn’t remember her? Is it so unreasonable for me to worry about that?
My gut says that'll never happen.
Then you really do have greater faith in mankind than I do. They walk on watching the women walking ahead. Sophia smi
You really think it's possible two people can be apart for so long and pick up right where they left off? Sophia reflects on the question.
I don't know. I hope it is.
Why are you doing this?
To find out, I guess. (smiles) Plus I think I've got a bit of a crush on your grandmother. He looks at her slightly disturbed.
Sophia sits at a desk with her laptop open. She starts to type. Stops for a moment. She closes the laptop. Somethin doesn't feel right.
Sophia, Claire and Charlie are loading up the rental car.
Before we go anywhere I need to be straight with you both. My being here is not entirely selfless. It started as that. (MORE)
SOPHIA (cont'd) And I do want to help. But I’d also like to write an article about what happens. I want to tell your story, Claire.
A bloody journalist! I should've known.
Hardly. I'm a fact checker. I've never had a word published.
And you think Gran's story is your ticket to being published. Yeah?
I think her story is a story worth telling. Claire smiles her approval.
Well I think that’s simply marvellous. We both get something out of it. It’s a what d’you call it? A win win. Sophia smiles appreciatively.
I’m so pleased for you both but where, exactly, do I fit in?
Don’t worry, dear. Every story needs a comedy character. She gets into the car. Sophia smiles at Charlie.
This is going to write itself. Something starts buzzing in her bag. She fishes around in and brings out her cell phone. She grimaces.
I missed Victor. I had it on silent all night. He's probably frantic.  46.
I would be. I’d have probably killed myself by now - in a most violent manner leaving a poignant note which would haunt you forever.
(from inside the car) Charlie! Sophia can't help but smile at Charlie as she dials Victo
I hope he's not too worried.

For everyone I'm sure.

Victor used to work at this little Italian place in The City. I'd go there to work every week. I'd get a double espresso and a water - no ice. And he'd come by my table, tell jokes, make small talk. Then one week he bought my espresso, a week later he bought me lunch, then dinner, a week after that he cooked me dinner at his place, and three months later I moved in with him.
How romantic. With a longing that tells us this was as romantic as it g

Charlie you're such a snob.

He's a chef actually. A talented one. He's opening his own place... (slight pause) It's gonna be great, I know it. He won't let it be anything else.
Sounds like quite a catch. Your mother must be pleased.
I'm sure she would be.  48. Claire looks worried she's made a dreadful assumption.

Moved on is more accurate. She left when I was little.

(shrugging it off) Don't be. I'm not. Charlie looks at her in the rear view mirror as she stare out of the window and sees that nothing could be further the truth as she displays a rare moment of vulnerability.

Charlie?! He takes Claire’s hand and starts for the car. Then the d opens. They stop and turn as ALFONSO appears at the door. he’s 73, dark and ruggedly handsome. Sophia and Charlie g
(in fluent Italian) Are you Alfonso De Annunzio? The man nods. Charlie and Sophia exchange a glance - we'v found him! - but alas Claire knows immediately that:  49.
That's not him.
Are you sure?
It's not him.
But he looks...
It's the eyes.
Do you remember what you were doing in the summer of 1951?
(smiles wistfully) Ah, the summer of 1951, I'll never forget it, I met the most beautiful girl with long, brown hair...
Nana! But Claire has already turned away, disappointed, and is walking towards the car.
They're not his eyes. It's not him.
We married that year ... and she gave me nothing but trouble from that day on! I curse that woman!
Right... He and Sophia follow Claire to the car as Alfonso continu raving from his doorstep.
I curse her eyes! I curse her teeth! I curse her mustache! They get into the car. A beat of silence.  50.

Are you for real?
If I actually knew what that question meant, I might attempt to answer it.
He can’t be the only Alfonso De Annunzio in Tuscany.

Are you suggesting we don't? Charlie looks at Claire. It's obvious she wants to keep looking. Charlie sighs as if to say "Fine".
This is madness. Total madness.

Claire is lying on a sun bed in the shade. Charlie swims relentlessly up and down the pool - quite clearly for exercise rather than pleasure. Sophia sits at a nearby ta working away at her laptop. She finishes typing.
Thirty six.
That many? Claire sighs. Sophia has an idea.

I might be able to find some pictures online. Give me a minute.  51. At this point Charlie hauls himself out of the pool. He h surprisingly well toned body. This guy obviously works ou Sophia can’t help but notice.
(quietly to herself) Whoa. She sees Claire smiling at her. She blushes.
Did I just say that out loud?
I believe “ripped” is the appropriate modern term isn’t it?
(smiling) Ok, here we go, I've found photos of two of them. Claire takes a look and sighs.
No. Sorry.
So that leaves us with thirty four.
(approaching) Thirty four what?
Contestants for Italian Idol.
Fantastic! He walks away drying himself off.
Is he really unhappy about this or just pretending?
A bit of both I think. Claire watches Sophia working on her laptop as if weighin whether she’s going to ask her what’s on her mind.
Tell me about your mother.  52.
(without looking up) Nothing to tell.
Indulge a nosy old lady. Slight beat. Sophia looks at this woman with such kind ey and sees someone who genuinely wants to know.

There’s nothing much to say really. I was young. I don't remember much. Then one day she just upped and left. Just like that. No warning, no note, no forwarding address, not even a goodbye or good luck.
How old were you?
I was ten.
And you haven't seen her since?
Don't expect I ever will.
That must've been very hard. Sophia shrugs as if to say "not really".
I started packing my own lunches, probably ironed a few more of my dad's shirts than I would have.
You don't ever think about trying to find her?

I used to. Until I realized that she didn’t feel like she could waste her time on me so why should I waste a minute of mine on her? Sophia looks down in an attempt to control her feelings. Claire takes her hand and gives it a squeeze.  53.
The three of them are having dinner.
Charlie have you told Sophia about the Green Alliance?
Can't imagine she'd care.
Try me.
Charlie’s going to stand for parliament on the environment ticket. Sophia looks genuinely surprised.
You know the kind of thing - planting trees, air fare taxes, bicycle lanes, eliminating cars from Central London - great idea, pity it doesn’t stand a chance, really.
That's amazing.
You look surprised.
I guess I am. I didn't have you pinned as a "Save the planet" type.
And what type did you have me pinned down for, exactly?
I don't know. I was leaning towards the "elitist Oxford prig" type but now that you mention it "self- satisfied do gooder" fits too.
Well thank you very much. Sophia laughs. So does Charlie. Claire smiles at this.  54.
Oh don’t be fooled by all the posturing he’s just a little teddy bear really. She ruffles up his hair.
Get off!
He’s still trying to work out our carbon print for this little jaunt.
Anther good reason not to have come.
He’ll have me planting trees for months. (she yawns) Well I'm off to my bed. You two be nice to each other now. She kisses them both on the head and leaves.
She's incredible.
Yeah she's alright. But with her gone it seems they have nothing to talk abou So they just sit there in silence. A pantomime of embarrassment. An exchange of awkward smiles. Then finall
Right. Well. Time to hit the sack. Sophia smiles she knows he's just trying to get out of th
It must be at least nine thirty.
Long day tomorrow. Need my rest and all that.
Oh of course.

Right. Alright. Good night then.  55. He gets up and strides off leaving her at the table. Then stops in the entrance. His back is turned to her for a mo then he swivels round and marches straight back.
Forgive me. Where are my manners?
I have absolutely no idea.
I don’t know what it is, but you seem to bring out the very worst in me.
I figured it’d be my fault somehow.
Please, may I buy you a night cap? A beat. She smiles politely.
No thanks. I'm tired.
Right. Of course. Apologies.
Accepted. He stands there for a minute, unsure what to do.
Well. Good night then. Again.
Good night Charlie.

A beautiful day in the Tuscan countryside. They drive alo with Puccini’s “La Boheme” blaring from the stereo. Charl is driving. He looks at Sophia curiously in the rear view mirror. Claire notices this and smiles to herself. La Boheme continues over the next few scenes.  56.

Alfonso, this is Claire, do you remember Claire?
Claire! Of course. Of course.  58. Alfonso takes off his sunglasses to get a better look at Sophia and Charlie instantly look at Claire. It’s not him
(quietly) Shit... He's confused her for someone else. Claire plays along so not to hurt the sweet old man's feelings. She hugs him.
It was good to see you, Alfonso.
You too, my angel. Thanks for visiting! Come back soon! He waves to them as they go - they made his day.
They walk to the car in silence.
That’s it for today I think.
One more?
She’s exhausted.
I am. Sophia sighs.
Sophia is on her cell in her room. Her notebook is open o the desk next to her laptop. She’s clearly been working o the story. The remains of her dinner are on a plate nearb
I hope we’re doing the right thing. She’s so full of hope one minute then deflated the next. The ups and downs are killing me, I can't imagine what's it like for her...  59.
Victor has a Bluetooth ear piece in. He's paying close attention to every detail about how the restaurant is run and not paying any attention to what Sophia is saying. Th

Did you listen to a word I just said?
I miss you beautiful. Sophia rolls her eyes - he's so transparent.
Miss you too. A WAITRESS brings Victor a plate of food. He smiles his thanks and wafts the steam coming towards his nose.
If you could see the plate of food I’ve just had put in front of me... Victor eagerly lays a napkin in his lap.
Hey. Can I call you back? I feel like I should have all my senses for this.

Sophia sits at the desk with her laptop open. She's looki at that cursor blinking at the end of a full page of writ She smiles - pleased at this. There's a knock at her door. She answers. It's Charlie.

Think she'll be OK?
Oh, yeah, yeah she’1l be fine. Tough as old boots that one. Don’t be fooled by the frail old lady act - she’s Churchill in a dress. Sophia laughs. Charlie smiles. He clears his throat.

Slowly.

You are.
Can I read some then?
No.

You're just going to have to trust me.  61.

You don't trust me?
(matter of fact) You're an American. Sophia can't help but laugh.
You're sure you won't let me read just a bit to ease my mind? Sophia shuts the door. From the other side of the door:
Is this one of those situations where you're really saying the opposite of what you actually mean?
It's not.
Right. Good night then.

Good night. They each remain where they are on either side of the clo door smiling and waiting for the other to move. Finally h moves away and she leans back against the door, more than little charmed.
Sophia is waiting in the lobby writing in her notebook. Charlie comes down the stairs and over to her.
Gran's not feeling well.
What is it? What's wrong?
I don't know.  62.
Should we call a doctor?
Best just let her rest. Sophia suddenly looks and feels very guilty.
I shouldn't have pushed her.
It’s not your fault. Truth is she made her decision the moment that letter arrived. And neither I nor the entire regiment of the Household Guard would’ve been able to stop her from coming.
But if I hadn't come back from the airport...

If you hadn’t come back from the airport I would've been denied the pleasure of spending a day in your glorious company showing you the sights of San Gimignano and Siena. Sophia smiles - she feels better already.
You can actually be quite charming when you put your mind to it.
Oh, don't let it fool you.
They drive together through the Chianti countryside.
So what's your story, Charlie?

You can be whatever you want.

She lives with me actually.
Well that makes all the difference.

I'm an only child. Sophia laughs - of course he is.

...And my parents were killed ina car crash when I was fourteen. Sophia’s mouth is still open from laughing but she now se incapable of either shutting it or speaking. She just sta
Hit head on by a tourist driving on the wrong side of the road. An American tourist. He reaches over and gently pushes her jaw closed with the tips of his fingers. A beat.
